Author: KU Leuven, Belgium; Klerkx, Joris; Verbert, Katrien; KU Leuven, Belgium; Duval, Erik; KU Leuven, Belgium
Title: Learning Analytics Dashboards
Notes:
Klerkx, Verbert & Duval, 2017 Notes

  • Article focussed on unpacking LA dashboards.
  • Definition: "learning analytics dashboards apply information visualization techniques to help [users/stakeholders]...explore and understand relevant user traces collected in various (online) environments." p.143
  • The idea of visualizing this data is to draw on humans' analytical abilities- this is not data mining where computers do everything.
    • LA dashboards mean to engage users tointeract with the data and use this to feed into design & implementation. Achieve this by making the data easy to understand and interpret, which is easier to do visually than presenting numbers  p.143-4
  • "Information visualization is the use of interactive visual representations to amplify cognition." p.144
  • Making dashboards interactive- using "dynamic interaction techniques"- allows users to explore data and identify what is most relevant or useful to them. Aim is to "promote awareness, reflection and sense-making" while helping identify and refine goals. p.144
  • Types of dashboard:
    • Those that help lecturers improve their teaching.
    • Those that help group work in settings where there is face to face interaction.
    • Blended learning environments.
    • Student Activity Meter/ SNAPP.
    • Increasingly trying to capture non-digital user traces.
  • Dashboard content: p.144-5
    • Learners' artefacts (like outputs/ products).
    • Learners' interactions.
    • Learners' use of learning materials.
    • Learners' time on tasks.
    • Learners' own self-assessment.
  • Before designing a dashboard, need to be clear about what you want to achieve. Key questions: p.146
    • Why have a visualization? What is the point of it?
    • Who will be the audience?
    • What will the visualization show?
    • How does the visualization support overarching goals?
  • Process of design & creation: securing and cleaning data, data analysis, preparing data, mapping design.
    • This all depends on the type of data! Needs to be appropriate.
  • Some rules:
    •  Bar charts can be effective. Stacked bar graphs seem to be more useful.
    • "Coordinated graphs" allow for deeper understanding of data.
    • Additional dimensions can just confuse.
    • Scatter graphs are useful for showing correlation.
  • The visualization process is iterative. Ideally, designers need to understand pedagogy and visualization techniques. Good to start by thinking about how the LA dashboard user will want to engage with the data. EG:
    •  Adopt user-centred design (UCD). p.149
    •  Comparing data, filtering, annotating, bookmarking, clustering, sorting, highlighting. p.148
Editor: Columbia University, USA; Lang, Charles; Siemens, George; University of Texas at Arlington, USA; Wise, Alyssa; New York University, USA; Gasevic, Dragan; University of Edinburgh, UK

Author: Niemi, Jarad; Gelman, Andrew
Title: Statistical graphics
Notes:
Neimi & Gelman, 2011

  • Emphasize the importance of clear graphics over beautiful ones.
  • Some key take-aways for good graphs:
    • Label your x and y axes! Keep these on the same scale.
    • Clear and not too busy x axis.
    • Remove repetition.
    • Make it easy for the reader to understand scale on the axes.
    • Think about what your reader wants or needs to know- and how the data you have can be presented best to meet this.
    • No need to have a graph which fills the whole screen (esp. in R).
    • No need for embellishment or "distracting elements".
    • Color can help clarify different pieces of data.
    • Graph should be interpretable.
    • You can tell a story by using same graph structure (i.e. easily comparable) with different data.
    • Use "small multiples" to also compare plots. Be consistent.
  • When designing a graph two key questions:
    • "Who is your target audience?
    • What are you trying to show?" p.2
  • Here, the authors focus on plotting new confirmed cases of measels rather than cumulative cases, and ensuring the date of the vaccination campaign, since the readers are more interesting in "visualising outbreaks as the number of infected individuals at a given time" p.2
  • Think of InfoVis as allowing the reader to see data at a high level, and understand it quickly. And then also offering further detail in subsequent plots (digging down).
  • Authors see the above- called "multilayer interactive graphics" as the way to tell stories in the future.

Author: Gelman, Andrew; Unwin, Antony
Title: Infovis and statistical graphics: different goals, different looks
Publication Title: Journal of Computational and Graphical Statistics
Notes:
Gelman & Unwin, 2012

  • Article about differences between statistical graphs and Infovis (information visualization).
  • Outline some of the issues in both statistical graphs and Infovis.
  • Argue both camps can learn from each other and call for more intersection- a key suggestion is not to cram too much into one graph, when two or more can better tell a story.
  • Statistical graphs:
    •  Focus on the 'correct' way to represent data rather than making the graph beautiful and attention grabbing. p.3
    • Look at making comparisons and letting the reader decide what to make of the data.
    • Motivated by "what can be got out of the available data" p.4
    • Always looking to compare.
  • InfoVis
    • Focused on "grabbing the readers' attention and telling them a story" p.4
    • Rely on more contextual information to help readers to understand the graph.
    • Draws attention to wider issues. p.4
    • Present numbers on their own p.6
    • Good at making data easier to read.
  • Exploratory graphs: what you do when you first have cleaned data to consider different views and ways to analyse the data.
  • Presentation graphics: when you chose one graphic and are concerned with "specifics and a single view" p.4
  • Thread throughout whole article is consider what your goal is- even a badly presented graph can be useful for capturing attention or imagination if that is what you want.
    •  Statistical graphs often aren't used to share findings beyond academics whereas InfoVis is increasingly used predominantly to communicate with the public p.5
  • InfoVis designers could learn from statistical graphs in that having multiple graphs, which provide more detail in each, can help with deeper understanding of the data once their attention has been caught p.5
    •  Quote Shneiderman's mantra (1996): "Overview first, zoom and filter, then details-on-demand." p.6
  • Tukey's principles for statistical graphics on p.7.
    • For qualitative/ descriptive not quant. (tables).
    • Comparison.
    • For impact.
    • Report not replace on data.
  • Authors outline their goals for graphics pp.8-9
    • Discovery- overview, sense of complexity, discover unexpected elements, small multiples.
    • Communication- display, story telling, attracting attention.
    • But you can't all both at once!!! Have to make a choice- hence understanding your goal and your audience.
  • Graphics are "part of a story rather than isolated objects" p.10 and we should think of them as parts of a whole. p.11
  • Bad graphics:
    • Hide information.
    • Confuse readers.
    • Are busy.
    • Have too much on them (data, measures).
  • The ideal purposes of both are p.14
    •     "Statistical data visualization, which is focused not on visual appeal but on facilitating an undersatnding of patterns in an applied problem...both in directing readers to specific information and allowing the readers to see for themselves." -> discovery
    • "Infographics, which ideally should be attractive, grab one's attention, tell a story and encourage the viewer to think about a particular dataset, both as individual measurements and as a representation of larger patterns" -> communication

Author: Grunspan, D. Z.; Wiggins, B. L.; Goodreau, S. M.
Title: Understanding Classrooms through Social Network Analysis: A Primer for Social Network Analysis in Education Research
Short Title: Understanding Classrooms through Social Network Analysis
Notes:
Grunspan, Wiggins, and Goodreau, 2014

  • Discusses social network analysis- appropriate data, methods, use etc. through the authors' own research into undergraduate SNAs and their impact on outcomes in a biology course.
  • SNAs usually study populations in naturaly-occuring or artificially bounded contexts.
  • Two hypotheses for SNA:
    • What affects relational ties in a bounded population.
    • How structure of ties can shape outcomes. p.167
  • Network types by number of types of actors:
    • Unipartite: one type of actor.
    • Bipartite: two types.
  • Networks categorized by nature of links:
    • Directed: relations have an associated direction.
    • Undirected: inherently bidirectional.
    • Binary ties: whether a tie exists or not.
    • Valued ties: ties containing further quant. data about the relation.
  • Collect data in line with needs (static or cross-sectional or longitudinal) and resources (census network cheaper than full network).
    • Ego-centric studies look at individuals and their environment- less focus on the ties.
    • Census networks collect data from the whole population.
    • Timing of surveys for data p.172
  • Density: how many linsk are in the network/ by total possible links.
  • Homophily: "a propensity for similar actors to be disproportionately connected in a relation of interest." p.169
    • Can come from social selection or social influence.
  • Relation measures:
    •  Dyad: any two connected individuals.
    •  Triad: any connected three nodes.
    • Transitive triad: linearly linked ties (A -> B -> C). Often indicates hierarchy.
    • Cyclical triad: A -> C, C-> A. Indicates egalitarianism. p.170
  • Actor measures:
    • Degree centrality: total connections nodes have.
      • Measures indegree and outdegree (i.e. popular or no shame- see class notes).
      • Useful for measuring equity in number of ties.
    • Betweenness centrality looks at those nodes which might be bridges in the shortest paths between two actors. p.170.
  • Data management:
    • SNA data often stored in edgelist or sociomatrix/ adjacency matrix.
    • Unipartitite sociomatrix: always square- undirected will be symmetric along the diagonal, directed will not. p.173
    • Matrices are not always square.
    • Important to keep rows and attribute data linked via unique IDs.
  • Authors suggest starting to analyze SNA data visually to generate a qualitative hypothesis.
  • Then explore structural changes in networks if comparing them.
  • Finally you can look at statistical analysis if you want to compare the SNA to another variable e.g. outcomes.

Author: Bowers, Alex J.
Title: Analyzing the longitudinal K-12 grading histories of entire cohorts of students: Grades, data driven decision making, dropping out and hierarchical cluster analysis
Short Title: Analyzing the longitudinal K-12 grading histories of entire cohorts of students
Notes:
Bowers, 2010 Notes

  • Bowers uses hierarchical cluster analysis and pattern visualization to show trends school performance across a cohort of students in two districts. This is to show how these methods can be used to present and analyze data in a meaningful way to support data driven decision making at the school level.
  • Success School Factor -> the variance between teacher assigned grades and standardized test scores being down to grades rewarding 'school' behaviors not just learning (i.e. listening, participation etc) p.2
  • What is HCA?
    •  A "multivariate statistical method" that "uses a series of nested correlation calculations, or distance measures, to reorder a dataset such that 'clusters' of data patterns are closest to each other in a list." pp.3-4
    • Allows you to create cluster trees or dedograms based on distance calculations. p.4
    • It "provides a way of organizing cases based on how similar the values for the list of variables are for each case" p.5
  • Dendogram: shows similarities (and dissimilarities) among the data by linking them with lines. Shorter horizontal lines reveal greater similarity, longer horizontal lines reveal less similarity. Vertical lines create clusters by connecting the closest rows. p.4
  • Heatmaps are useful because humans can identify patterns in color better than with numbers.
  • Why the clustergram? (the HCA, cluster tree and heatmap)
    • Allows us to "discover a taxonomic structure" p.5
    • Descriptive statistics aggregate data and inform you about the central tendency of a sample, and don't give you individual-level information. p.2
    • Often statistics use only one or two course outcomes, but this can hide course failures that occur much earlier. p.3
    • HCA allows for analysis of longitudinal data, enabling better analysis of long term trends. p.3
    • You can then do system-wide analysis p.12
    • Presenting data in tables may inhibit comparison across students, especially if there are many observations. p.3
    • With a heatmap you can keep the individual data for each student but show this over time and support pattern recognition and identification of clusters p.4
  • Limitations of HCA and heatmap.
    •     Can't do it for thousands of observations/ students.
  • Results:
    • The results showed that within the lower-attaining clusters, 38% dropped out versus 6% in the higher-attaining cluster p.10
    • The data was also useful for identifying potential dropouts between K and 6. p.10
    • Also showed four interesting clusters of high-high, low-high, high-low and low-low achieving students. p.11
    • Overall, Bowers found between K and 4 grades fluctuated and then stabilized. The accuracy of identifying drop-outs was good compared to previous methods p.12
    • Between grades 4 and 8 appears to be a critical time for future achievement p.13

Author: Hanneman, Robert A.; Riddle, Mark
Title: Introduction to social network methods
Notes:
Hanneman & Riddle Notes

  • Notes difference in data presentation and what the data shows between conventional social science and SNA data. pp.1-2
    • SS: rectangular array. Columns contain scores on attributes/ variables/ measures. Focus on comparison between attributes/ variables.
    • Network data: square array. Columns are observations and each cell is evidence of relationship between actors. Actors described by relations not attributes.
  • A key priority of NA is "seeing how actors are located or 'embedded' in the overall network." p.2
  • Second priority of NA is "seeing how the whole pattern of individual choices gives rise to more holistic patterns" p.2
  • Nodes/ actors
    • Actors are not sampled independently,
    • NA often looks at different levels of analysis (i.e. 'nested' design) p.3
  • Populations, samples, boundaries
    • NA look at whole populations within a boundary, often through census and not sampling are they part of a population. --> NB this has implications on inferential statistical analysis. p.4
    • Boundaries are those decided by researcher (known a priori) or created by the actors themselves. Some are naturally occurring, others are not.
    • You can include many levels of analysis (modalities and multi-modal studies) in NA- i.e. networks within networks etc. More than two modes of analysis is rare and difficult. p.4
  • Sampling ties
    • Full network methodscollect measurements on all actors and all relations. Give most information. Expensive, difficult.
    • Snowball method. Useful for looking at unique populations.
    • Ego-centric networks with alter connections: when you start with a "selection of focal nodes (egos) and identify the nodes to which they are connected..." Useful for tackling large populations p.7. Good for analyzing network density, prevalence of reciprocal ties and cliques. p.8
    • Ego-centric networks, ego only: focus on the one actor not the network. Can give incomplete picture. Useful for understanding local social structures. p.8
  • Multi-relational networks under explored and methodologies less developed p.9
  • Scales of measurement
    • Important since different scales need to be treated with different mathematical operations. p.9
    • Binary: most common. 0 relation absent, 1 relation present. Sometimes, more complex scaling is put into binary coding by having a 'cut point' and re-scoring.  p.10
    • Multi-category nominal measures: coded by type not strength. Dummy coding and using binary measures. Can lead to artificially low density. Sometimes binarized.
    • Grouped ordinal: ordered in strength- so show 'gradiations', hard to deal with. p.11
    • Ordinal measures: can rank strength of relations. Can show degree of intensity but not always equal differences. Hard to take advantage of. p.11
    • Interval measures: most advanced. Relation strength rated on scales. Because continuous, have more options for mathematical & statistical tools. Not fit for every network though.  p.12
  • Statistics and social network data
    • SNA closer to 'mathematical' social science than 'statistical'.
    • Because population is  not a sample, and data is kind of 'determinisitic'. p.12
    • Networks are in most cases "non-independent by definition. Consequently, conventional inferential formulas do not apply to network data" p.14
    • Can do some inferential statistical analysis: see page 14.

Author: Galyon, Charles E.; Heaton, Eleanore C. T.; Best, Tiffany L.; Williams, Robert L.
Title: Comparison of group cohesion, class participation, and exam performance in live and online classes
Notes:
Galyon, Heaton, Best & Williams, 2016 Notes

  • Article looks at whether class participation and group cohesion changes from a face to face class to online-hybrid class where students meet and work online- evaluate student assessment data.
  • They find that the live classroom yields the higher exam performance, group cohesion, and participation.
  • They test the hypothesis that greater class participation would increase group cohension and therefore lead to improved exam performance.
  • Method: pp.6-7
    • Performance measured by GPA (self-reported) and exam.
    • Live class participation self-reported, online collected by website.
    • Self-reported group cohesion.
  • Results:
    • "course modality (live or online) may significantly affect the level of group cohesion and class performance, regardless of participation levels in class discussion." p.10
    • Even if live and online participation is the same, cohesion will be less online -but there are limitations to measuring cohesion and interaction online p. 10
    • Live class performance was higher, as was self-reported cohesion.
    • Positive relationship between group cohesion and exam performance.
